Peace and grace from God the Father through Christ.I had not established the Church of Christ by the suffrage of many, dearest Henry, when Simon Grynęus, a learned and pious man, taught me through his letters, I gave you to read them, as usual, so that you could examine with me what should be answered to him in a serious and very difficult matter.I understood that you were somewhat offended by this opinion, which I most approve of, not because Grynęus, or the brothers in Moravia have thought so, but because it is very closely allied to the sacred Scriptures, to the example and fact of Christ and His apostles.I am sorry that you are offended, whom I have loved from the heart for several years now, especially now, yet I cannot reject it against my conscience, which I judge to be true.Meanwhile, I have read what you have written to our Berchtoldus about excommunication and the Church, which is indeed clear, learned, and brief, as all your writings are, yet it does not oppose our opinion, but rather gives it support.
And first of all, I do not dwell on the definition of excommunication.The thing itself is sufficiently clear from the words of Christ and Paul.Nor do those seem to have gone far astray who called that censure and ecclesiastical discipline, which, as well as the Church, we now lack without reproach to faith and Christ.And yet Christ and Paul manifestly teach that the Church of Christ has pseudochristians and false brethren, who are justly excluded, not slain.But here, as I think, we agree.
Let us then speak, according to your division, of him to whom excommunication is given.
But what power is given or can be given to magistrates, of what sort it is, I do not yet see proved by you, at least not firmly.And because the affair of the Church and of excommunication is almost the same, let us speak of both together.
For my part, I think excommunication is given by Christ to the Church.But magistrates and the Church are very different things, not such that they can never coincide, but their own nature cries out that they are separate and distinct things, if not Scripture, certainly the thing itself.For there was a magistrate when there was yet no Church of Christ.Wherefore, as excommunicated from Christ, so excommunicated from men cannot be but in the power and jurisdiction of the magistrate.

I think that excommunication was given by Christ to the church. However, the magistrate and the church are very different things, not in such a way that they can never come together, but by their nature they are separate and distinct, if not by scripture, at least the facts themselves cry out. For there was a magistrate when the church of Christ had not yet come into being. And it is clear from Acts 4:1ff and 21:18ff that even the heathen and quite tyrannical magistrate opposed the church when the apostles gathered the church in Jerusalem and preached repentance in the name of Jesus. Christ teaches that excommunication has been given to the church in Matthew 18:15-18, Paul in 1 Corinthians 5:1-5. Now I do not deny that kingdoms are separate and distinct and that the duties and responsibilities of each are different (one is above material things and bodies: Romans 13:1-7, 1 Timothy 2:1-3, 1 Corinthians 6:1-6, the other above souls), but both are from God and servants of God, so that it is possible and sometimes happens that one can pass from one camp to the other and be in both at the same time. An example is Joseph, Nicodemus, the centurion, and Demas. For although they held a terrestrial magistrate, they were nevertheless co-opted into the church of Christ. And even from the church faithful can and, if possible, should be taken into the magistrate. Now nothing prevents someone from being in both orders, as is clear from the preceding.
Let us now return to excommunication. Excommunication of the church is given by the elders to whom the church entrusts it, who are also called the church because they represent it. Such were the prefects of the Church of Christ, as is evident from the epistles of the apostles, men of great age, mature and serious, of blameless life and approved morals, as you wisely bring from Tertullian, whose opinion I greatly approve. They preside over the church in these matters which regard the discipline of morals, even correction, the settlement of controversies, and civil cases which are not capital or otherwise belong to the magistrate. For these are preserved to the magistrate and rarely occur within the church - because "the law of the Spirit of life" etc. [Rom 8:2], but if they do occur, those who reject the yoke of grace are subject to such law.

For it is nothing else to commit excommunication simply to the magistrate, whatever he may be, than to betray the kingdom and doctrine of Christ. Henry, do not think that I am speaking these things from affection or a desire to curse or out of hatred for anyone, or that I think myself holier than others. For I am conscious of my own weaknesses and uncleanness, and I do not reject them in my heart, I pray for their salvation, and I pray that they may come to a knowledge of the truth. But I think it is important for the glory of God, for the glory of Christ, that such people should be publicly known as such, and should not be admitted into the Church of Christ, nor tolerated in it, much less allowed to excommunicate or preside over the Church of Christ or cast their votes on Church matters, for there is nothing that the Church of Christ has in common with such ne'er-do-wells and impious people (always impious I mean those who openly rebel against Christ's word and work; for I know that even impious people are in the Church, but they are not manifest, they lie hidden until they make themselves known), but they should be rejected, not admitted, and treated as heathens; indeed, they were never in the Church of Christ. By 'evil in the Church' I do not mean that evil people should be in the Church, but that they are in the Church, that is, they join themselves to the members of the Church. Nor can we judge who are hypocrites and feigners. But when they become manifest, they should no longer be tolerated in the Church, but excluded, until they are overcome by shame and promise to lead a new life. Furthermore, even if members of the Church sometimes fall ill and fall - "for the righteous falls seven times and rises again" [Prov 24:16] -, this does not happen out of stubbornness and impiety, but out of frailty, soon they acknowledge their fall, are overcome with shame, accept correction and discipline, repent and grieve. But if anyone is so stubborn that after one or two admonitions they persist in transgression, as a warning to others they are excluded from the Church and treated as heathens - and certainly it is no small thing for the Church of Christ to cast them out. I mean excluded from the Church, not from the city or the senate or the court or the guild, not from the republic. For a citizen or a senator can be one who is not in the Church of Christ. But if, like the Prodigal Son, he humbles himself and returns with tears and signs of repentance and begs for forgiveness, then the bosom of the holy mother Church must be open to him. Mary Magdalene, Zacchaeus, Matthew, Peter sufficiently show to whom the Church of Christ must be open: those who by certain and undoubted signs have shown themselves to be held by a desire for Christ and for a better life.
But if the fault is such that it deserves to be punished by public laws (which rarely happens to the pious), it is handed over to him who bears the sword. I think that excommunication is a milder discipline than to be handed over to the magistrate who carries the sword.

Each is free to do as they please insofar as they are not prohibited by the laws of Christ or magistrates. Those who are outside of the Church of Christ, however wicked they may be, are not to be despised or rejected in heart, but rather pursued with all kindness by the example of our lives, our innocence, justice, faith, humility, meekness, patience and charity, so that they may be drawn to Christ, provoked by benefits, and aided by our anxious prayers to God, that they may turn and live until God enlightens them with His light and draws them with His Spirit, so that they may join us in one body. If we obtain this, we give thanks to God whose kingdom is enlarged. If we do not obtain it, we admire and revere the hidden judgment of God, to whom we must leave them. If this method had been observed, my Henry, the great man Zwingli of blessed memory would still be alive, as well as the other brave and pious brothers, the Swiss Republic would still be preserved, the mild and meek people of Zurich would be saved, the Church would be purer, more fervent, holier and more constant, all offices and ministries in the Church could be treated, provided and administered more worthily, and the poor more faithfully cared for. But now, all things are confused and disturbed. The Senate appoints to the Church those who are unworthy, the ignorant to bishoprics, they cheat the poor, and cover up crimes.

For in this passage I understand the sons of God to be those who, led by the Spirit of God, walked innocently before God, and the sons of men to be those who, led by the desires of the flesh, lived in the world.

You said, "We are not all Christians who are counted among the Church of Christ". If you look at these words closely and carefully, Henry, they will do more against you than for you. For I too can truthfully say the same: Not all who are enrolled in the senate are Christians. So what will you do to those who nourish adultery, usury, and other sins you wish to put an end to, and are themselves afflicted with the same disease you want to cure?- "If you ask for the exclusion or punishment of the one who has sinned, he will be afraid of being snared with the same noose which he would set for them." So he will cleverly disguise it. In short: the words with which you want to take away the power of excommunication from the Church and give it to the magistrates, I shall use as evidence that it should be taken away from the magistrates and given to the Church. For the more learned and worse the senators are, and the more authority they have, the more they sin and make use of many tricks, and are afflicted with worse diseases than the simple common people. This should not be feared among the elders of the Church and reputable men. No proof is needed, since we have daily examples of this which are not obscure.
You also said, "What if someone from the magistrates behaves badly or cunningly acts in opposition? Let him be removed from his position and a more sincere one substituted in his place." Is this serious, Henry? You see every day how good and reputable men are driven from the senate by scoundrels. So far is it from being possible for the good to drive out the bad, nor is it allowed or perhaps even expedient for us to remove the worst from the magistrates. But if someone among the elders of the Church acted cunningly in opposition, we could easily change him and substitute another in his place. I say this, Henry, not to despise the magistrates. I have learned from the teaching of Christ and the apostles to obey all magistrates. But since they are Gentiles or even worse than Gentiles and enemies of the gospel (as we usually see today, since this is what our sins deserve), I think it absurd, contrary to the teaching of Christ and the apostles, to give them anything, much less excommunication. Yet I know that we must obey them, even if they are enemies of the gospel, so long as they otherwise fulfill their duties rightly.

"But not all of us are Christians," you say, "who are considered to be within the Church of Christ," etc. If you carefully and thoroughly consider these words, my Henry, they will do more against you than for you. For with the same words I can truly say: Not all are Christians who are enrolled in the Senate. What then will you do with those who nurture adultery, usury, which you wish to be extinct, in their bosom and are, themselves, afflicted by the disease which you want to be cured? - "If you seek the exclusion or punishment of the one who sinned, he will be afraid lest he be strangled by the same noose that he would bind them with." And so he will skillfully disguise himself. In brief: I shall take the individual words with which you strive to deny and transfer the power of excommunication to the magistrates and use them to prove that it should be taken away from the magistrates and given to the Church. For the senators, the more wise and the worse they are, and the more authority they have, the more they harm and strive with many wiles, and they are afflicted by worse diseases than the simple common people. In the elders of the Church and in approved men this should not be feared. There is no need of proof, since we have daily examples of this that are not obscure. - You say further: "What if one or two of the magistrates degenerate or craftily take contrary counsels? Let them be deposed from their high office and a more sincere one substituted in their place." Do you really mean this, Henry? You see every day how the good and approved are expelled from the Senate by the knaves. So far is it from the good being able to expel the evil, nor is it allowed to us, perhaps it is not even expedient, to strip the worst from the magistracy. But from the elders of the Church, if one should craftily act contrary, we could change him without difficulty and substitute another in his place. I do not say these things, my Henry, to despise the magistrates. I have learned to obey all magistrates from the doctrine of Christ and the Apostles. But since they are nations or even worse than nations and enemies of the Gospel (as we usually see today, for so they deserve for our sins), I think it absurd, against the institution of Christ and the Apostles, to commit anything to them, much less excommunication. But I know that we are to obey them, even if they are enemies of the Gospel, provided they otherwise properly discharge their office. For this Peter teaches.
But concerning the manner of excommunication, it is quite clear from Christ in Matthew 18 [15ff] and Paul in 1 Corinthians 5 [1ff]. And I am pleased with what you think in this matter, except that I do not want the magistrates to be the Church. For excommunications from the Church are of less consequence than to endanger the life of the one excluded. But if the crime be such that the magistrates should use their sword against him, this I do not fight over. But it is certain that Christ gave the sacraments to His Church.

Perhaps someone might say: "This is to disturb the Church, this is to bring about schism in the Church." I answer with Elijah: He who seeks his own glory, not that of Jesus Christ, who loves and follows his own figment contrary to the divine institution, disturbs the Church. He who draws away men from God and draws them after himself, instead of leading them to God, who, overcome by truth does not yield, but persists stubbornly, divides the Church.
These things I do not write, that I may rashly and inconsiderately innovate, but that, the disease being known, remedies and drugs may be considered, that the body may be so restored, that no shock to the body or dissolution of the members may ensue. If we shall have followed the word of the Lord and have sought Him with our most earnest prayers, He will find out ways and will show, that we may have at length a holy, pure and Christ-like Church.
Meanwhile, I, as much as my smallness permits, will not be wanting to him that studies for the glory of God. But if this opinion be less approved by thee, thou art not less to me, nay, I will rather pray to God, that He suffer thee not to err in any thing, and be present with thee in all. And surely I shall depart sooner than ever I would attempt any thing against thee. Let every one stand in the grace of God.
